lines.text: Alright, I can finally dig into this sweet sweet tome!
For investigation purposes, and not for illegal knowledge purposes.
Uh, right. Sure.
...Huh.
What is it?
Well, this book…
It’s sort of a religious text for a demon cult.
So it’s a spellbook, then.
What? No, dude. Don’t you know anything about magic?
‘’Don’t I, the cop, do illegal things, like knowing things about magic?’’
Seriously, man. Dealing with this stuff is your job.
And calling in ex-cons like you to handle the magic side of things is part of that job.
Bleh. Whatever.
Anyway, the difference is- most magic is about trapping demons, and forcing them to give you powers.
<c=#FF00FF>Worshipping</c> demons is a totally different thing. These guys must’ve been total kooks.
I coulda told you that. How’s that relevant?
Well, Stop Magic and Go Magic are derived from a ring of <c=#FF00FF>elemental demons,</c> which are known for being, uh…
More… hierarchical? Better-organized? They’ve got more of a social structure than most of the slavering murder-beasts down there.
Good for them. Get to the point.
The point is, this book tells demon-worshippers how to, um, ask the elemental demons for stuff. Rituals for buying magic, instead of taking it by force.
This ritual was supposed to be an animal sacrifice- they had to <c=#FF00FF>light five candles</c> around a pentagram, and <c=#FF00FF>sacrifice a live goat.</c>
And what that ritual was supposed to be?
A shortcut to <c=#FF00FF>leveling up</c> in Stop Magic and Go Magic, from the first level to the second.
...Wait, what?
Meaning… these guys <c=#FF00FF>weren’t already level 2.</c>
But that means…
Yeah. I think we have the <c=#FF00FF>answer to your question,</c> right here.
A cultist’s manual for demon-worshipping. It was open to a ritual for leveling up from level 1 to level 2.
The ritual involves lighting five candles around a pentagram, and then sacrificing a goat. Nothing too fancy.
